feed.title: Combined summary - Proposal: Unlocking Dust UTXOs as Miner Transaction Fees

entry.title: Combined summary - Proposal: Unlocking Dust UTXOs as Miner Transaction Fees
entry.summary:
In a series of exchanges among Bitcoin developers, a new proposal was discussed aimed at addressing the issue of economically unviable dust UTXOs in the Bitcoin network. Dust UTXOs are small amounts of Bitcoin that become stranded or unspendable due to the cost of moving them exceeding their value. This situation has been exacerbated by the increasing value of Bitcoin and transaction fees, leading to a growing "dust horizon" where such UTXOs bloat the UTXO set and affect fungibility.
The proposed solution allows users to voluntarily designate their dust UTXOs as transaction fees through cryptographic authorization, enabling miners to claim these UTXOs directly without the need for traditional spending methods. This approach presents benefits for all parties involved: users can reclaim value that would otherwise remain stranded, miners gain an additional source of fee income, and the network benefits from a reduced UTXO set size. Implementation of this proposal would be carried out as a soft fork, ensuring backward compatibility with nodes that are not upgraded. It emphasizes voluntary participation, simple security models based on familiar signature verification processes, and introduces minimal complexity to Bitcoin's validation logic.
The proposal specifies a fixed dust threshold of 546 satoshis, aligning with Bitcoin Core's current dust limit for P2PKH outputs, though it suggests that a dynamic threshold might be more suitable to accommodate fluctuating network conditions. Wallet software would be responsible for calculating what qualifies as dust based on current mempool conditions, focusing on economically rational decisions for users.
Key technical aspects include the use of a special OP_RETURN output format in transactions to designate dust UTXOs for miner claiming. This method is designed to be efficient, especially when multiple dust UTXOs are designated within a single transaction, as it removes the need for users to include full input scriptSig/witness data. Furthermore, the proposal outlines potential future extensions to support more complex script types such as multisig, aiming to maintain focus and feasibility initially.
Despite the positive aspects, concerns were raised regarding the proposal's assumptions and potential limitations. Questions included why the dust limit was fixed at 546 satoshis, considerations for dust UTXOs owned by more complex scripts like multisig, and whether the size of the OP_RETURN output could pose technical or economic barriers. Additionally, the effectiveness of the proposal in reducing on-chain bytes compared to traditional spending methods was questioned, along with its overall worth considering the effort required for a soft fork and wallet updates.
The discussion also touched on alternative solutions to address metadata size issues, such as utilizing SegWit witness data or implementing Schnorr signatures to reduce signature sizes, thereby making transactions more economically viable even during high-fee periods. The possibility of using new witness versions to encode information efficiently was mentioned as a way to circumvent standardness limits and reduce transaction weight significantly.
This dialog reflects the ongoing efforts within the Bitcoin development community to find innovative solutions to technical challenges, aiming to improve scalability, fungibility, and overall network health while balancing security, economic incentives, and user experience concerns.
